headline: Amazon's Bull Case Hinges On 'Two Things' Holding, Says Futurum Equities: 'Does Not Need A Recession To...'
summary: As Amazon.com Inc. (NASDAQ:AMZN) is set to report its quarterly earnings on Thursday, Futurum CEO Daniel Newman and Chief Market Strategist Shay Boloor share their thoughts on what investors should watch out for. AWS And Consumer Both Must Hold Amazon's earnings hinge on “two things staying true at once,” which are strong AWS demand and a resilient U.S. consumer. While performance has beaten expectations, the stock has lagged as lofty consensus leaves little room for upside surprises. Bull Case

headline: Amazon (AMZN) Q4 2025 Earnings Call Transcript
summary: Joining us today to answer your questions is Andrew Jassy, our CEO, and Brian T. Olsavsky, our CFO.  As you listen to today's conference call, we encourage you to have our press release in front of you, which includes our financial results as well as metrics and commentary on the quarter.  Additional information about factors that could potentially impact our financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, including our most recent annual report on Form 10-K and subsequent filings.

content.title: Amazon (AMZN) Q4 2025 Earnings Call Transcript

headline: Amazon’s US$200b Capex Puts AI Growth And Regulation In Focus
summary: Amazon.com (NasdaqGS:AMZN) plans to spend about US$200b in capital expenditure in 2026. The company aims to fund artificial intelligence, chip development, robotics, and infrastructure projects. This announcement follows a modest Q4 earnings miss and growing investor focus on returns from AI spending. At the same time, Germany's antitrust regulator is imposing restrictions and fines on Amazon's marketplace practices. For you as an investor, this combination of very large planned spending...

headline: Amazon shares tank on investor jitters over AI spending
summary:
STORY: Amazon shares plunged in after-hours trade Thursday, falling around 11%.

The tumble came after it projected a surge of more than 50% in capital expenditures this year.

The e-commerce giant plans to pump $200 billion into its AI efforts in 2026, joining other tech giants in a spending spree to build out artificial-intelligence infrastructure.

That has some investors worried about returns on the investment. 

Amazon Web Services' revenue grew to $35.6 billion in the December quarter.

While that marked a rise of 24%, the pace of increase was slower than rivals like Google and the figure was overshadowed by the company's capital spending surge.

Speaking to analysts, Chief Executive Andy Jassy said it was easier for smaller competitors to post stellar growth rates. 

But the numbers will concern investors, with AWS accounting for over 60% of the firm's operating profits. 

The results are the latest sign that Big Tech will not be halting AI investments any time soon. 

The top four so-called 'hyperscalers' - Amazon, Microsoft, Google and Meta - are expected to collectively spend more than $630 billion this year.

One analyst told Reuters that "Amazon has to invest at these levels just to stay in the race."

But this week's earnings suggest Wall Street has a message for tech titans: keep spending if you like, but we want to see signs that returns are coming.

headline: AT&T Fiber Expansion And Amazon Alliance Put Valuation Gap In Focus
summary: AT&T (NYSE:T) has formed an alliance with Amazon Web Services and Amazon Leo to modernize U.S. connectivity infrastructure. The collaboration focuses on using cloud services and satellite technology to support broadband expansion, including into underserved communities. AT&T has also completed the acquisition of Lumen’s Mass Markets fiber business, extending its fiber footprint to 32 states. These moves mark a material shift in AT&T’s network strategy and service mix beyond routine quarterly...

headline: Big Tech to Spend $650 Billion This Year as AI Race Intensifies
summary: The spending planned by Alphabet Inc., Amazon.com Inc., Meta Platforms Inc. and Microsoft Corp., all in pursuit of dominance in the still-nascent market for AI tools, is a boom without a parallel this century.  Each of the companies’ estimated outlay for this year would set a high-water mark for capital spending by any single corporation in any one of the past 10 years, according to Bloomberg data.

content.title: Big Tech to Spend $650 Billion This Year as AI Race Intensifies
content.summary: The spending planned by Alphabet Inc., Amazon.com Inc., Meta Platforms Inc. and Microsoft Corp., all in pursuit of dominance in the still-nascent market for AI tools, is a boom without a parallel this century.  Each of the companies’ estimated outlay for this year would set a high-water mark for capital spending by any single corporation in any one of the past 10 years, according to Bloomberg data.
